KUR

ğ“‚“ â‰  ğ“Š– â€œKarâ€ is likely the most recognisable international sign cluster in the age of urbanization and syllabic writing from the 4th millennium BC. It combines a wonderword with a kind of wondersign, akin to the spread of alphabets throughout many cultures:

ğ’†³ kur ĞºĞ°Ğ¹Ğ° ğ’†  ki ğ”—œ ku ğœº KU ğ˜¾ ka ğ€ KA ğ‘£ ĞºĞµÑ€Ğ»Ğ° ğ”•† â€¢KAR ğ”•ˆ KA ğ”•‡ ğ€¤ ğ˜¿ QE ğŠ¨ Ê˜ q /kÊ·/ â°– Uku ğ’‰½ KURâ‚‚ ğ’„¯ á¸ªar ğ“Š– [1] ğ’ƒ¸ kÃ¡r ğ’ƒ¼ gar
ğ““ ğ“Š– ğœ°¸ ğœ°´ ğ’†  perfect continuum in Indus script, though its value so far is unproven.

It combines two similar sounding concepts, Kreuz and Kreis (cross and circle) or Kreuz and Karos (cross and squares) into a very persistant phonetic and logographic unit of "KAR".

â€œKarâ€ has two main semantic meanings "city" and "mountain", connected through the concept of tell (city-hill). Later also via extension: "country". Connections to "cold" and "stone" may be secondary or basal but not part of the logographic KAR cluster under investigation.

ğŠ” Naturally associated with the number 4 (sometimes ğŠ¼ 3 or Ï€ ), semantically via city court quarters, also supporting the "kar" root in some branches.

Traces of this sign or its underlying wanderword can be seen on any atlas: From Novgorod via Merhgarh, Ankara, Sakkara to english courts. As with many wanderwords as part of names, this very recognizable pre-/suffix is still all too often reanalized per instance by folk etymologies and Bad-Linguistics.

Representatives of Kar can have all vowels a,e,i,o,u,â€¦, so labeling this cluster 'Kar' is somewhat arbitrary, K-R would be more fitting. For extended discussion of connections between this well defined group and other far reaching concepts see KUR!

Representatives of Kar are visible in near all logographich systems.

The phonetic R ğ”–± of ğ”•† KAR is often omitted in syllabic practice, reduced to ğ”•ˆ KA, just as only the 'be' of beta (Î²) is used in alphabetic usage.

Phonetics inside and outside the syllabaries were far from stable though:
Especially words for city (or related signs) corroded from kar > car > Å¡ar sar > á¸«ar > har via common sound-change chains. On the other hand it might have been reattached conciously to similar concepts and variants.

ğ“Š– had probably many phonetic readings over time, but symbollically it fits the above description of Kar perfectly!!
ğ“Š– does have indirect evidence for repesenting the KAR/court cluster though: ğ“ ğ“‹“ ğ“‚‹ ğ“ ğ“ ğ“€ even if via complement.
ğ“ fits phonetically but has no city connotation, unlike similar ğ“Š–.
ğ“Š¨ may be an imperfect specimen without circle connotations via secondary qursi â‰ˆ chair readings.
